items.title: Jacob L. Moreno publishes early sociometry work and popularizes sociograms—precursors to modern network visualizations.
Network and graph-based methods spread through sociology/anthropology, enabling formal analysis of ties and group structure.
Mark Granovetter shows that weak ties often carry novel information and opportunity, shaping later organizational network thinking.
Centrality, cohesion, brokerage, and community concepts become standard analytic tools in social network analysis.
Ronald Burt formalizes 'structural holes'—advantages of bridging disconnected groups; becomes a core ONA lens.
Rob Cross & Andrew Parker's work (e.g., 2004) helps operationalize ONA for leaders: diagnosing silos, bottlenecks, and key connectors.
Email, chat, calendars, and collaboration tools provide large-scale relational data for continuous organizational network measurement.
Enterprise ONA platforms and people-analytics offerings scale up network measurement, reporting, and interventions.
Network science becomes mainstream in business/tech; hubs, scale-free networks, and diffusion ideas influence organizational analytics.
Graph databases and open-source libraries make it practical to compute centrality, communities, and influence on large org interaction graphs.
Remote/hybrid work reshapes communication patterns; organizations increase interest in collaboration analytics and network-informed interventions.
Organizations combine ONA, graph databases, and AI to detect emerging silos, overload risk, skill flows, and simulate change scenarios.
